11:02 am
BE

David "Shanghai" Tang?

PM

Yep

PM

Cancún is a paradigm of “distance lends enchantment to the view”. From the air, it looks fabulous, then as you descend, you notice ominous masses of concrete blocks, and by the time you get into the terminal, you are hit by a hurricane of alarm and ugliness. Hordes of tourists with hairy shins jostle in the hot and humid luggage hall. Mexican customs officers, all decorated to the hilt, look menacing. Outside, an ocean of touts bombard visitors, the taxis are cheap and smelly, and luggage has to be guarded closely in case it is snatched. Along the coast hideous buildings cluster around the shoreline. The whole place is a giant blancmange of a holiday camp, cramped with screaming children, obese parents and mobster-like Latinos, with their ageing mistresses soaked in suntan oils and smeared with pillar-box lipsticks. Inside the hotels there is the echoing hum of conveyor belts of monster buffets decked out with mini-umbrella cocktails, and monotonous Caribbean steel pan music. I spent a day exploring that commercial cesspool while in transit to Havana. It was a stopover that nearly ended my faith in travelling. But thankfully, the people I saw there were robot tourists, not cerebral travellers.

After an unfair and politically motivated LIBOR show trial, Tom Hayes was scapegoat sentenced to 14 years in prison on 3 August 2015 (later reduced to 11 years on appeal).

In March 2016, the same court issued an order meaning that Tom and his family have to sell almost everything they own, including the family home and Tom and his wife's wedding rings, to pay the UK Government nearly £900,000.00 as the “proceeds of crime” or else Tom will have to serve even more time in prison.

11:16 am
BE

Since mid-February, AHL Diversified has fallen 13% and we estimate is 15% below performance high water marks. Alpha and Dimension are also down and we estimate are just below high water marks. Only Evolution ($2.9bn of total $19.2bn AHL FUM) remains 4% above high water marks. In contrast, at 31 Mar 16, 71% AHL was at or above high water.

BE

Without AHL, performance fee generation looks challenged. There is little help elsewhere. At 31 Mar 16, 9% performance fee eligible GLG FUM was at high water mark, and the asset weighted relative performance at Numeric was -0.7% Q1. We reduce our Performance Fee PBT forecast from $181m 2016E to $64m. This is the main driver of a new lower $236m 2016E PBT forecast, down 35% from $361m.

BE

Dead Zone
Man reports 1H16 results on 26 July. Until then, we are in a news “dead zone” with the only accessible data being fund performance. We expect AHL and GLG performance prints to drive share price direction during this time.
Key Risk: M&A
We liked the acquisition of Numeric in 2014, which successfully helped plug an underlying earnings growth gap. With ca. $500m surplus capital and no share buy-back this year, Man has firepower to do something similar again. This would be, in our view, the best solution to the fundamentally subdued FUM and earnings growth outlook in Man’s core franchises. But we see execution as unlikely.
Double Downgrade
We upgraded Man to Buy in December, reflecting EPS growth, dividend yield, our (incorrect) view that AHL is now less volatile and the potential for Man to become a full service alternative investment solutions provider. We see this still as a potential long-term outcome, but believe we were wrong on the rest. AHL volatility and lack of flow or performance elsewhere mean we now forecast -43% YoY EPS 2016E. We see the shares fully valued at 17.3x 2016E PE. We Downgrade to Sell, with a new 120p target, in line with lower EPS forecasts.

BE

Yep. That's the structural flaw of outsourcers.

BE

Here's Cazenove.

BE

 £70m exceptional provision to be taken in UK Construction. The
group previously highlighted three energy from waste contracts that
caused FY15 UK Construction profits to be reduced to break even, and
today is increasing the provision estimate for one, the Glasgow contract,
to £70m. The issues relate to the design, procurement and installation of
the gasification plant, together with supply chain problems.
 Could this get worse? Of course further downside is possible, but this is
the best estimate at the present time and there could be upside if
recoveries exceed expectations. Of the other two energy from waste
contracts, we note that one is completely finished and the second is well
advanced.
 Rest of the group trading in line. Trading in Support Services remains
robust, recently winning a significant facilities management contract for
the United States Air Force’s UK estate. The group’s Middle Eastern
businesses are performing as expected, with the comment that “some
uncertainty” remains for Equipment Services, also made at the prelims.

11:23 am
BE

.... (Which seems to remain Cazenove, incidentally. Not sure why the old name had fallen off the Rolls note yesterday.)

BE

Should note that Liberum's Joe Brent downgraded to sell on Wednesday

BE

11:25 am
BE

Here's what he makes of it this morning.

BE

Unfortunately we have not been able to speak to management. Clearly there is a £70m exceptional. Perversely, this may result in an increase in our Construction estimate, given that we had assumed some weakness on waste to energy in our underlying EBIT.

BE

We increase our net debt estimate by c. 10% to £347m, but by £70m in 2017 to £360m. A 2017 Net Debt EBITDA of 2.3x is amber and approaching red in our view. This increases the urgency of a sale It also makes the prospect of capital returns or acquisitions less likely. Aside from the exceptional, we think working capital dynamics are negative.

11:26 am
BE

We continue to assume a 15% fall in EBIT from £100m to £85m, with no real growth, and assuming the high end of the guided £10m to £15m NLW impact. As previously announced, Interserve has been awarded the £230m facilities services contract for the USAF UK Estate. We remain cautious about the UK outsourcing sector; political stasis, NLW (particularly at Initial) and too much risk transfer. At the key Transforming Rehabilitation there have been very few metrics reported to date.

BE

Management indicate ‘good momentum’ across its international markets, notably the UK and Far East. We currently assume a 19% fall in EBIT. In reality, we may never know. But we would not expect anything other than a positive pitch given that the business may be up for sale. Management say that the strategic review is ‘proceeding to plan’, but we note the surprise departure of the MD yesterday. .We still believe that a sale is likely, although we think a price of c. £350m is likely (c. 40% EBITDA premium to Ashtead), lower than the original market thoughts of £350m to £500m. This would be 18% dilutive in our estimates, or more dilutive to higher consensus numbers. We think there may be limited appetite for a an asset with c. 50% Middle East exposure and we note the cautious reports from the IMF last week and MEED, the local construction experts.

11:36 am
BE

ISAT posted Q1 results below expectations and cut core FY 16e revenue guidance.
The company highlighted tough trading conditions in its legacy business and also
indicated that getting GX operational was taking longer than expected, delaying
revenue generation. Positively, ISAT expects more revenues from Ligado and
remains confident about the midterm outlook. However, in our view these results
illustrate well the challenges the company is facing (volatile demand, ramp up of
new product). Longer term we recognize the growth opportunities but also the fast
growing supply in the industry. We cut estimates, and even after the stock price
correction we consider that the valuation does capture the different downside risks.
We remain UW.
Weak Q1. Inmarsat posted a weak set of results with revenues and EBITDA below
consensus (-3.5%, -2.1%) and Barclays estimates (-2%, -1%). Core revenues were
down -2.3% yoy (-4.9% in Q4 15). The miss was driven by Maritime and Enterprise.
Government was better than expected.
Guidance change. Inmarsat has lowered its 2016 revenue guidance (excluding Ligado)
by $50m to $1,175-1,250m, this lowers the midpoint of the range from $1,263 to
$1,213 (-4%). A revised Ligado agreement was also announced increasing the revenues
from Ligado by $35m over 2016-18.

BE

Cutting estimates. We update our numbers for Q1 results and the lower 2016 revenue
guidance. We cut revenues by c. 1%/5%/3% for 2016/17/18 and cut EBITDA by c.
1%/8%/5%. We now stand at the lower end of the guidance range at $1,182m
revenues excluding Ligado for 2016 (midpoint of guidance $1,213m) and at $1,389m
for 2018 ($1,525m guidance midpoint).
Remain UW, PT cut to £8.6. We remain UW and cut our PT to £8.6 from £9.5 to reflect Link to Barclays Live for interactive charting
our lower estimates. Inmarsat trades on 26x Dec 16E P/E, 10.8x EV/EBITDA, and offers
a 4.5% dividend yield.
Risks. An upside risk is that Intelsat reduces its fleet expansion plans. A downside risk is
that GX becomes outdated before end of life as data needs grow too fast.

BE

That last point is quite interesting, and I've not got the knowledge to speculate.

11:37 am
BE

Is Global Xpress the Videodisc of broadband satellite standards?

BE

Dunno. Maybe. It's a risk, certainly.

BE

(@Roddy: ha!)

11:39 am
BE

And Berenberg.

BE

● Cut to guidance was a big surprise: The weak Q1 trading and signs of a
slower Global Xpress (GX) ramp led management to cut the 2016 guidance
that it gave just nine weeks ago. We had perceived the existing guidance to
be challenging, yet achievable, but the timing of the guidance cut came as a
big surprise to us, and questions the visibility that management has. The
low end of the new guidance range ($1,175m) would actually result in a 1%
decline in core revenues from 2015. We now see 2016 as yet another year of
transition, as the market now looks to 2017 for evidence that Inmarsat can
grow into its high multiples. We appreciate the complexities in forecasting
the Inmarsat business, but after the 2016 guidance cut, the market will now
seek further evidence that the 2018 guidance remains achievable.

BE

● Ligado outcome the only positive: While we had already been aware that
Ligado (previously LightSquared) had opted for the 30MHz option, it was
only at the Q1 release where the exact financials were disclosed. Ligado is
deferring some payments, but Inmarsat has use of the spectrum. The net
result for Inmarsat was modestly better than our expectations.
● Medium-term concerns remain: The troubled shipping market, depressed
energy industry and weaker business aviation segment has led us to
question our medium-term forecasts. We have, however, for now taken the
view that this is cyclical and not structural, and that by 2018 things have
improved. Within aviation, we believe Inmarsat will sign further GX and
S-band aviation contracts, but have concerns around the ease with which it
does and the subsequent impact on financials. We do not think that GX
offers the most attractive technological solution, highlighted by the recent
capacity deal with Telenor, and thus Inmarsat needs to incentivise airlines
by taking the operational and financial up-front capex.

11:40 am
BE

● Reported forecasts up, core business (ex-Ligado) down: Given the new
agreement with Ligado we are now comfortable to include the revenues
received from 2016-18 in our base-case assumptions. Previously we had
captured the value from this opportunity in a separate sum of the parts,
and we still use this methodology from 2019 onwards (66% likelihood of
perpetual payments). This has resulted in material upgrades to our
reported estimates, which more than offset the underlying downgrades
from weaker trading. More details can be seen in Figure 1 on page 3.
● Valuation not cheap even after underperformance: As stated above, we
still see downside risk to our medium-term estimates, particularly after the
recent 2016 guidance cut. However, even on our current estimates the
stock looks far from cheap trading on a blended 2017 P/E (includes 66% of
Ligado opportunity) of 25.9x and blended EV/EBITDA of 10x. The better
Ligado outcome broadly offsets our near-term cuts to underlying
estimates. Our marginally lower DCF-based GBp880 price target implies
the shares are fairly valued and we thus reiterate our Hold rating

BE

(@nichoman: anecdotally, that's my feeling too.)

Deutsche quick-read.

BE

The current consensus forecast is for a 200k
print this afternoon although it’s interesting to see that the range of forecasts
are from as low as 160k to as high as 315k. Our US economists are sitting at
the lower end of that range and are forecasting for a below-market 175k gain.
This is based on their view that upon closer inspection of the sectors
responsible for job growth last quarter, the details reveal that retail trade has
accounted for a disproportionate share of these gains (in the fact the pace of
which is the fastest since 1994). They expect the pace of hiring in this sector to
moderate somewhat closer to its 12-month average this month.

BE

11:54 am
BE

Different measures of wage growth are sending conflicting signals about the pace of underlying wage inflation. To gauge the impact of the labor market on inflation, we recommend focusing attention on the employment cost index and the Atlanta Fed Wage Tracker rather than average hourly earnings. The average hourly earnings series released each month with the payroll data may be among the most watched of all wage indicators, but has not been the most reliable predictor of future inflation. Neither we, nor the Fed in our view, would take an uptick in average hourly earnings alone as a strong signal of imminent upward pressure on prices. We suggest bearing in mind that the connections between labor market tightness and price inflation are loose.

BE

Which is from Andrew Labelle's US Economics Weekly, just for a different spin.

12:02 pm
BE

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: AGM trading update is stated by management as in-line, reporting revenues up
12% y-o-y reflecting mainly the Landmark acquisition. Sales are down 6% on a LFL
basis which appears slightly soft due to mild weather impacts.

BE

Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: Signature Flight Support grew 1.8% organic, despite impact of an unusually mild
winter. ASIG revenues -12% organic due to announced contract losses, and low de-
icing activity. Aftermarket Services revenues -11% organic, with conditions challenging
in the ERO market. Integration of the Landmark acquisition is ahead of plan.

BE

Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: The slightly slow revenue start to the year appears to have been countered by good
profitability at Signature such that there is no net change.
Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: Limited impact on the investment case which is focused on the Signature business
and Landmark acquisition.

12:03 pm
BE

And Caz for the longer take.

BE

We retain our Neutral rating following the release of BBA’s Q1 trading
statement which is broadly in line with our expectations. Signature
continues its market outperformance, is seeing good drop through to profit
and the integration of Landmark is described as “ahead of plan”. However,
markets remain challenging, with business jet activity growth slowing and
aftermarket conditions remaining tough. Overall we reduce FY16E/17E
estimates by -1%/-1% as upgrades to Signature are slightly more than
offset by reductions to ERO which now accounts for only 3% of FY16E
OPP. BBA trades on FY16E/17E PERs of 14.3x/12.1, EV/EBITDAs of
10.1x/8.9x, FCFe yields of 5.8%/8.2% and dividend yields of 4.7%/5.0%.
 Q1 trading. Signature continues its market outperformance, growing
+2% organic, in spite of a mild winter impacting de-icing revenues and
traffic in some locations, seeing good drop through to profits. ASIG fell
-12% organic due to contract losses and lower de-icing revenues but the
group commented that the operational performance remains robust.
Conditions in ERO continue to be challenging and despite a good
performance in Legacy, caused the Aftermarket division as a whole to
decline -11% organic.
 Market conditions tough. Adjusted for an extra day due to 2016 being a
leap year US Domestic business jet flying activity grew +0.9% in Q1,
reducing to +0.7% overall as International traffic fell -0.7%. This
compares to +1.7% Domestic growth in Q4 15 and +2.4% in Q3 15.
 Changes to earnings estimates. For FY16E/17E we reduce our
Aftermarket profit forecast by -13%-12%, reflecting worse than
expected decline rates in ERO, but this is largely offset by +3%+4%
profit upgrades in Flight Support, attributed to a stronger drop through /
cost recovery in Signature. Overall, our FY16E/17E group EPS estimates
reduce by -1%/-1%. We note the FY16E ERO OPP contribution falls
from 5% to 3%. Our December 2016 price target is unchanged as the
small estimate changes are offset by peer group valuation changes.
